title: NEW WHEELS! - My Electric Hummer Has Liquids inside?
description: We got new tires for the Electric Humvee! HUGE thanks to Trail Built Off-road for hooking us up:  See what new wheels and tires fit your machine. Today as we near completion of our Military HMMWV turned electric, we get some new tires, add gear oil to the hubs, as well as get the Transfercase and Torquebox buttoned up and ready to roll. Cuz rolling will come soon.   Watch all the EV Humvee build videos in order HERE:    Get my Shirts and Razor Knife here!    Anker is named as the Official Charging Partner of JerryRigEverything:    *Follow me for updates!* Instagram:  Facebook:  Twitter:   LARGE tool kit:  Travel Tool Kit:  Mega Tool Kit:  Plastic Pry tools:  Metal phone opening tool:  Replacement phone parts:   The camera I used to film this video:  The Lens I used for this video:  Wide angle lens:  And this Metabones adapter:  This is the drone I use:   TO SEND ME STUFF: See my P.O. Box on my 'About page':   JerryRigEverything assumes no liability for property damage or injury incurred as a result of any of the information contained in this video.  JerryRigEverything recommends safe practices when working with power tools, automotive lifts, lifting tools, jack stands, electrical equipment, blunt instruments, chemicals, lubricants, expensive electronics, or any other tools or equipment seen or implied in this video.  Due to factors beyond the control of JerryRigEverything, no information contained in this video shall create any express or implied warranty or guarantee of any particular result.  Any injury, damage or loss that may result from improper use of these tools, equipment, or the information contained in this video is the sole responsibility of the user and not JerryRigEverything. Only attempt your own repairs if you can accept personal responsibility for the results, whether they are good or bad.
transcript: [Mechanical noise of garage slowly opening] She's getting super close. You would think that since this is an electric vehicle with no gas tank or engine, that there wouldn't be any liquids inside. Turns out though there's actually four different kinds of liquids... and did you know that you can mail tires to yourself? [pallet jack rolling] Let's get started. [Intro] Today we're going to be mounting these brand new massive tires onto my electric military Humvee because the tires on there now are bad. You might be thinking to yourself, 'But Jerry, they're still round.' After tires have been sitting on a vehicle for a while they become brittle and crack. And this is a 1995 military Humvee and the tires have been on there for a very long time. There's a YouTube channel from a guy called Weston Champlin who tried to take his military Humvee that bought and drive it across the United States and he blew two tires almost immediately because they were so old, brittle, and cracked. So new tires are super important. I got these tires from TrailBuiltOffRoad.com. Huge thanks to them for jumping on board and sponsoring this video. Trail Built Off Road has massive inventory of wheels and tires. It's nice because the tires come mounted and balanced. So when I stick them on the Humvee I can just drive out of here ready to go. Of course after we get the batteries off of my table and into the back seats. The mounting is free, the balancing is free, and even the shipping is free when the wheels and tires are bought together as a package. Plus, on TrailBuiltOffRoad.com I can just input my vehicle and instantly see all of the wheels and tires that will fit. It made things pretty easy. I'll leave a link down in the description so you can try it out for yourself. Now, I've heard it's been said, out with the old, in with the new. [Drilling sounds] So it might get a little loud in here since we're working on the cooling system at the same time. But this right here is one of the tie down points. I have seen people stick a piece of re-bar through it and a rope and kind of use it as a makeshift wench sometimes, but I don't think that's its initial purpose. Luckily I'll be able to leave these on when I install the new wheels. [Drilling sounds] And all of the tires are off. After looking at this pile, there's not a whole lot left of the original Humvee. Apparently there's not a whole lot of match up between the old world and the new. And also, you've probably seen a couple videos on YouTube where vehicles tips over on lifts when the tires are being removed so I have put down some jack stands underneath the frame to make sure that doesn't happen. The goal here with this project is to not end up on a fail video. We're kind of running out of room in my garage because we have two complete vehicles but one vehicle body. Like with everything else that I've taken out of the military Humvee, I've waited so we can see what the weight difference it between the diesel powered vehicle and the electron powered vehicle. And we're going to do the same thing with the tires. So this tire right here is hovering off of the ground, and currently we are at 157. Now I think that the tires between the old ones and the new one which you can see back there, they're going to be relatively similar, but this does probably have a steel run flat inside. I made a video about run flats over on the What's Inside YouTube channel where we actually popped a tire and then saw what was inside a run flat. So if you're curious you can go watch that. But long story short, the run flat allows the vehicle to move even if the tire itself is gone. It won't be riding on the rim, it will be riding on the run flat...which is basically a huge chunk of durable metal. Now let's see what the new tires weigh. The new tire's hanging suspended off the ground with this very nice tread. We are at 128, which according to my math is 30 pound difference per tire. And since there are 4 tires, 120 pounds we've saved by just swapping out the tires. It'll be interesting to see where we're at with the final video which should be coming pretty soon. We're getting way close. Before I can install the new tires though, I want to upgrade the portal hub covers right here. The military Humvees and the Hummers all have portal axles which increase the torque at the tire and give more ground clearance. It's a gearbox, and because it's a gearbox, it does generate heat. And by adding these cooling fins it can dissipate that heat by 30%. It's not one of those things that's like super important, but since we're adding a whole lot of power, might as well get rid of heat where we can. One of the four liquids I talked about earlier was the oil inside of this hub. Since there are gears rubbing together creating friction, the oil is in here for lubrication. The oil coming out of my hub looks super clean so it must have been changed recently. One cool thing about the drain plug is that there's a magnet on the inside which is here to help catch any super small metal shavings so they don't rattle around inside of the gearbox. [Ratchet sounds] And as you can see, now that the plate is gone, there are the gears in all of their glory. That gear is actually much larger than I thought it would be. So we have the little gear up there coming in from where the motor used to be. And then the larger gear right here headed out to the wheels. That's crazy. Unfortunately though, it can't stay transparent forever. And our new heat sink portal cover can go in place with its new hardware. The nice part about the new one is that it has a clear window inside so we can see how much oil is inside and if it's at the correct level which is important when there is moving parts involved. Now the portal axle covers have been upgraded. Take a look on this side. They are all ready to go. It is time for the new tires. When it comes to tires and wheels I'm not super picky. I wanted something pretty close to stock, meaning 12 inches wide by 37 inches tall, while at the same time being pretty low key. Not super flashy. So I went with these matte black wheels, and some aggressive all-terrain tires with a load range of D I'll still be able to tow well over 10,000 pounds assuming everything goes smoothly of course. And they still have a 50,000 mile warranty. When upgrading your wheels and tires, you'll hear two different words: offset and backspace. Offset means how far away from center the spokes are inside of the wheel. And backspace means how much room you have on the inside of the tire. I used both of these measurements to make sure that the outside of my tires lined up with the body, but you can use the same information to stick your tires out farther or even recess them a bit like they were on the stock Humvee. And of course all of this information is on TrailBuiltOffRoad.com. They make it easy. Plus they even have a snowflake right here so I'm pretty sure they'll even work in the snow. Here in Utah all weather tires are pretty important because as it gets colder the rubber stops being as grippy. I learned that the hard way when a ladder I was standing on with rubber on the bottom was freezing and it slipped out on the asphalt and I broke my wrist. Rubber is rubber and tires are made of rubber, so getting rubber that sticks in the winter is super important. I also wasn't a huge fan of how the old tires didn't line up with the frame where the new tires line up perfectly and maybe stick out a little. It's already a wide vehicle and we don't need to make it any wider. It is extremely nice though that I was able to ship these to myself because right now we only have a drive-able range of about 3 feet since we are still connected to the batteries here. But you know, maybe in the next video we'll toss those in the back and take it for a real drive. I also do have 5 tires instead of 4. This one's going to be a spare that I'll mount in the truck bed. We'll have plenty of room back here once I clean up the wires, and I'll put the spare back here when I go off-roading and maybe take it off for driving around town, because with an electric vehicle you do increase your range with the less weight that you have inside, which is why Tesla's don't include a spare with their cars. I assume they did the math and figured out that people don't get flats very often and when they do it's worth it to just get a tow. But as for me, I will have a spare on hand if I ever need it. So the portal axle filler plates have been upgraded, the new tires are in place. And I think since we're here we might as well check to make sure everything's working. If we come over here to the ignition, listen for the second click, flip us into forward. And when I push on the throttle we should get tires spinning. Nice. Everything is still working but that only covers one of the four fluids I talked about earlier. There are three left. For the next splash of liquid, we have to get the Humvee off the ground. I'm just saying, those look pretty nice from the air. Also, it'll be way nice when I can walk around my garage without the fear of being zapped. The thing we're working on next is the transfer case, the thing that allows us to have 4-wheel drive. And that is right here. I also totally forgot that since we have a hole in the floor, we could have done all of this with the Humvee on the ground...but since we're here... One interesting thing with this transfer case is since it's universal it can be clocked at any angle. To compensate for that, advanced adapters has given a side tube so no matter what angle the transfer case is clocked at, you can still see what level the fluid is. So once we put our two quarts of fluid inside we can mark the level and then just fill it to that same point when it comes time to change the oil. All of these gear oils are slightly different different viscosities, different colors. The stuff going into the transfer care kind of looks like liquid cotton candy and probably just as unhealthy. I'll have to change the oil in this transfer case after about 500 miles, the break in period, and sew this permanent marker line as well as the zip tie will help me know which level to fill it back up to once I drain it all out. And the third liquid, this royal purple stuff, goes inside of the EV torque box from Torque Trends. It's basically the same concept as all the rest of them. It's a gear box that generates heat and needs lubrication. The little thing you see here on the top is where air can vent out as it heats up or cools down, but for the most part everything is self-contained. If things get super intense and I find that these gear boxes are heating up more than they should, I can always add a small pump and circulate the oil through them. And there you have it. All of the liquids that I'm using inside of my electric vehicle. The 4th is the coolant which we haven't gotten to yet, but we have built the manifolds and I'll explain all of that in a future video...might not be the next one. The pile of parts that we don't need is getting bigger and the pile of parts that we need to install is getting really small. And huge thanks again to Trail Built Off Road for sponsoring this video and hooking us up with some sweet wheels and tires. As always, wheels and tires are kind of a personal preference so I'm curious to hear what you would have gone with. Would you have chromed it out, gone with with more spokes, or maybe slapped some Tesla wheels on there? Let me know down in the comments. We're getting super close to finishing and I'm super excited. If you haven't subscribed yet hit that subscribe button, turn on notifications so you don't miss when we pull this thing out of the garage for real. Come hang out with me on Twitter and Instagram. And thanks a ton for watching. I'll see you around.
